bibl.title: Letter fragment to Howard A. Kelly, March 4, 1905

div1.p: The writer informs Kelly about a yellow fever epidemic in Norfolk, Virginia, in 1855.

div1.head: Letter fragment to Howard A. Kelly, March 4, 1905
div1.opener:
Norfolk, March 4th. 1905.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
Baltimore, Md.
My dear Dr. Kelly,
div1.p:
I would have answered your letter sooner, except that
I have been trying to get you everything I could on the Yellow
Fever Epidemic of 1855. And I have not yet found the medical report
written by my grand-father, Dr. Wm. Selden, but I will try again to find
a copy, if I cannot find my own. I will however be glad to lend you
the books by Forrest and Armstrong, neither of whom were physicians.
Consequently some of their conclusions are a little peculiar.

My grand-father, who had seen a good deal of Yellow Fever did
not believe it contagious, but thought it due to something which
could be carried in the hold of a vessel. This is brought out by Arme-
strong who considers it due to “a Miasma”, a theory resembling the
old theory for Malaria. Thus on page 26 he says, “It was by the
breaking out of the hold of that steamer that the fatal miasma was let
loose.” The fever was also said to be carried by the wind, and only
to be caught at night (pp. 187, 8, & 9). I have also frequently heard
that the Fever would appear first on the ground floor, and that
cases would not appear at the top of the house for some days. Armstrong
says further that secluding oneself within the town will not pro-
tect from the Fever, and that the only safety is in flight to a
distant place. Cases of Yellow Fever appeared in Norfolk people, who
had gone to Hampton, Richmond, and Baltimore, where some died, but no
infection was spread by them.

The facts just given you can all be explained by Dr. Reed's Mos-
quito Theory, for I have found the Stegomyia in Norfolk, where it un-
doubtedly was in '55.

The infected ship came to the dock on June 19, having had the Fever
on board, and the first local case seems to have occured in a workman, who
had been aboard of her, and who was attacked about July 2, There is
a possible earlier case in a woman who lived near where the ship lay (Armstrong p. 170), and
was seen by a physician on June 30. Both of these cases were probably infected by
Stegomyia, imported on the steamer. From these cases the Stegomuia of
Portsmouth were probably infected, but no cases originated away from
this locality till Aug. 7, (Forrest p. 28). The disease then gradually
spread in a Northerly direction, the mosquitoes being carried by
the prevalent South winds. The appearance of the Fever first on the
ground floor of a house, can be explained by the mosquito's habit of
staying close to the ground, when in the open. Armstrong's observation
on the futility of secluding oneself within the infected town, and
that no cases resulted from those that developed after they had
left Norfolk can also be well understood in the light of Dr. Reed's
hypothesis. The observation that the Fever was only caught at night
does not seem to accord with what I have read of the habits of the
Stegomyia.

Norfolk has in other years repeatedly had Yellow Fever brought to
its doors, without having further cases develop. They were frequently
treated in the Naval Hospital, just across the river, and Dr. Herbert
Nash, who was long our Health Officer tells me that he has often had cases
on a barge a few miles down the river, and that he always brought the
convalescents to the hospital here, and that contagion never result-
ed. This corroborates Dr. Reed's observation that convalescents
are not dangerous.
